advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Imagine a microcomputer with all the design savvy, ruggedness, and sophistication of the best minicomputers.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by dozens of interface, memory and processor option boards. One that can be Interfaced to an indefinite number of peripheral devices including dual floppy discs, CRTs, line printers, cassette recorders, video displays, paper tape readers, teleprinters. plotters, and custom devices.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by extensive software IncludIng Extended BASIC, DISK BASIC, DOS and a complete library of business, developmental, and Industrial programs.<br> ImagIne a microcomputer that will do everything a mini will do, only at a fraction of the cost.<br> You are imagining the Altair 8800b. The Altair 8800b is here today, and it may very welt be the mainframe of the 70's. <br><br> The Altair 8800b is a second generation design of the most popular microcomputer In the field, the Altair 8800. Built around the 8800A microprocessor, the Altair 8800b is an open ended machine that is compatible with all Altair 8800 hardware and software. It can be configured to match most any system need.<br> MITS' plug-In compatible boards for the Altair 8800b now include: 4K static memory. 4K dynamic memory, 16K static memory, multi-port serial interface, multi-port parallel interface, audio cassette record interface, vectored interrupt, real time clock, PROM board, multiplexer, AID convertor, extender card, disc controller and line printer interface.<br> MITS' peripherals for the Altair 8800b include the Altair Floppy Disc, Altair Line Printer, teletypewriters, and the soon-to-be-announced Altair CRT terminal. <br><br> Introductory prices for the Altair 8800b are $840 for a kit with complete assembly instructions, and $1100 for an assembled unit. Complete documentation, membership into the Altair Users Club, subscription to "Computer Notes", access to the Altair Software Library, and a copy of Charles J. Sippi's Microcomputer Dictionary are included.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Olivetti M10, the portable professional micro-computer, here comes why."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This November 1982 advert introduces the new CoCo 1 price : $299 instead of $399.<br><br> Even if the advert said:<br><font color="#666666">"Hurry - this fantastic offer ends december 31, 1982" </font><br>the price never came back to $399.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Graphics examples of the optional graphic card.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JULY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"access to the Forth power" <br><br> "with the Jupiter Ace, enjoy profesionnal experience of Forth"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Here comes Sirius 1 : the micro-computer which has an elephant memory"<br> ...<br> "A new era for computing"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>This reseller advert shows the initial price list from 1982 and the new prices of June 1983, about 40% less expensive.</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 2 x 3.5'' floppy discs, PC format; CD-ROM single speed; 80 MB hard-disk
computer.description:
The FM Towns II is a follow up to the FM Towns (read this entry for more info).
The FM Towns II could read CD audio. 5 LED displayed the sound volume and two buttons was used to change volume.
Graphics video features were very powerful: - One could display up to 800 sprite (16x16) on one video frame, - Zoom and screen rotation were hardware features. Display could be rotated to any angle using one single command. - Texts, Sprites and Graphics used three different RAM areas. They could be easily displayed simultaneously.
computer.graphics: from 352 x 232 up to 640 x 480up to 1024 sprites (16x16)
computer.keyboard: Full stroke 123 (!) keys with function keys and numeric keypad
computer.media: 2 x 3.5'' floppy discs, PC format; CD-ROM single speed; 80 MB hard-disk
computer.name: FM Towns II

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TOWER VERSION #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Note in this picture the way the CD tray opens, as well as the fact the case has a fold out handel on top for easy transport. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles Maib</b> for picture and info</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT PANEL CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles Maib</b> for picture and info</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MONITOR</strong></font><br><blockquote>The monitor matches the CPU and even has the FM TOWNS logo on it. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles Maib</b> for picture and info</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TOWER BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> External Floppy disc drive unit connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Analog RGB video connector<br> <b>(3)</b> 3 expansion card housings<br> <b>(4)</b> Serial RS-232 connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Parallel printer DB25 connector<br> <b>(6)</b> SCSI connector<br> <b>(7)</b> Stereo audio IN<br> <b>(8)</b> Stereo audio OUT<br> <b>(9)</b> Monitor grounded plug<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles Maib</b> for picture and info</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the 386-DX processor (marked A80386DX-16 IV)<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles Maib</b> for picture and info</p></blockquote>
